title: GitHub for Non-Developers
description: Learn how to use GitHub to interact with open source projects, suggest changes, report issues, and contribute to workflows—no coding required.

sections.title: Why GitHub Matters for Open Source
sections.body:
GitHub is the world's largest platform for open source software development. While it's built for developers, it's also a powerful tool for anyone who wants to participate in open source projects—including product managers, designers, writers, researchers, and community members.

You don't need to write code to make valuable contributions. GitHub enables you to:

• Report bugs and issues you discover
• Suggest new features and improvements
• Propose workflow and process changes
• Contribute documentation and guides
• Participate in discussions and planning
• Review and provide feedback on proposals
• Help organize and prioritize work

At Builder, we believe that great products come from diverse perspectives. Non-developers bring crucial insights about user experience, business logic, and community needs. GitHub provides the tools to turn those insights into actionable contributions that shape the future of open source projects.

sections.title: Understanding GitHub Basics
sections.body:
Before diving into workflows, let's understand the core concepts:

Repository (Repo): A project's home on GitHub. It contains all the files, documentation, and history of a project. Think of it as a folder that tracks every change.

Issue: A way to track bugs, feature requests, questions, or tasks. Issues are like tickets that help organize work and discussions.

Pull Request (PR): A proposal to make changes to a project. Even if you're not writing code, you can create PRs to update documentation, suggest process changes, or propose new content.

Fork: Your own copy of a repository. You can make changes in your fork without affecting the original project.

Branch: A parallel version of the project where you can make changes safely. Think of it as a draft that doesn't affect the main version.

These concepts work together to create a collaborative workflow where anyone can contribute, and changes are reviewed before being merged into the main project.

sections.title: Getting Started: Setting Up Your GitHub Account
sections.body:
Creating a GitHub account is free and takes just a few minutes:

1. Go to github.com and click "Sign up"
2. Choose a username that represents you professionally
3. Verify your email address
4. Complete your profile: add a photo, bio, and location
5. Enable two-factor authentication for security

Profile Tips:
• Use a professional photo or avatar
• Write a clear bio describing your role and interests
• Link to your website or portfolio
• Your profile helps others understand who you are and what you bring to projects

Once your account is set up, explore GitHub by:
• Following projects you're interested in
• Starring repositories you find valuable
• Watching repositories to get notifications about updates
• Exploring the "Explore" page to discover new projects

sections.title: Reporting Issues and Bugs
sections.body:
One of the most valuable contributions non-developers can make is reporting issues. Your fresh perspective often catches problems developers miss.

How to Report an Issue:

1. Navigate to the repository's "Issues" tab
2. Click "New Issue"
3. Check if a similar issue already exists (search first!)
4. Choose the appropriate issue template if available
5. Fill out the form with:
   • Clear, descriptive title
   • Steps to reproduce the problem
   • Expected vs. actual behavior
   • Screenshots or examples if relevant
   • Your environment (browser, OS, etc.)

Best Practices:
• Be specific and detailed
• Include screenshots or screen recordings
• Test on different devices/browsers if possible
• Be respectful and constructive
• Follow up if developers ask questions

Example Good Issue Title: "Documentation link broken on Getting Started page"
Example Bad Issue Title: "Help!" or "Something's wrong"

Remember: Every issue report helps improve the project, even if it seems small. Your user perspective is invaluable.

sections.title: Suggesting Features and Improvements
sections.body:
As a product manager or user, you have unique insights into what features would be valuable. GitHub makes it easy to share these ideas.

Feature Request Process:

1. Check existing issues to see if your idea has been discussed
2. Create a new issue with the "Feature Request" label (if available)
3. Clearly describe:
   • The problem you're trying to solve
   • Your proposed solution
   • Why this would be valuable
   • Potential use cases or examples

Writing Effective Feature Requests:

• Start with the user's problem, not the solution
• Explain the "why" behind your suggestion
• Provide context: who would use this? When? How?
• Consider edge cases and alternatives
• Be open to discussion and refinement

Example Structure:
"As a [user type], I want [goal] so that [benefit]."

Example: "As a product manager, I want to see a roadmap visualization so that I can better communicate project timelines to stakeholders."

Pro Tip: Engage with the community. Respond to questions, provide additional context, and help refine the idea through discussion. The best features emerge from collaboration.

sections.title: Proposing Workflow and Process Changes
sections.body:
Non-developers often have valuable insights about how projects can be better organized, documented, or managed. GitHub provides tools to propose these improvements.

Common Workflow Improvements:

• Documentation structure and organization
• Issue templates and labels
• Contribution guidelines
• Release processes
• Communication protocols
• Onboarding procedures
• Community guidelines

How to Propose Workflow Changes:

1. Create an issue discussing the current process and proposed improvement
2. Get community feedback and consensus
3. If it involves documentation, create a Pull Request with the changes
4. Reference the discussion issue in your PR
5. Work with maintainers to refine and merge

Creating Documentation PRs:

Even without coding skills, you can:
• Edit markdown files (GitHub's web editor makes this easy)
• Improve clarity and organization
• Add examples and use cases
• Fix typos and formatting
• Translate documentation

Step-by-Step for Documentation PR:

1. Navigate to the file you want to edit
2. Click the pencil icon (Edit this file)
3. Make your changes in the web editor
4. Preview your changes
5. Write a clear commit message describing your changes
6. Click "Propose changes"
7. Fill out the Pull Request form explaining your changes
8. Submit and wait for review

Remember: Small improvements add up. Every typo fixed, every clarification added, makes the project more accessible to others.

sections.title: Participating in Discussions
sections.body:
GitHub Discussions (when enabled) and Issues provide spaces for community conversation. Your participation shapes project direction.

Where to Participate:

• Issue comments: Add context, ask questions, share experiences
• Discussion forums: Engage in broader project conversations
• Pull Request reviews: Provide feedback on proposed changes
• Project boards: Help prioritize and organize work

How to Contribute to Discussions:

• Ask clarifying questions
• Share your use case or experience
• Provide additional context or examples
• Help others understand proposals
• Suggest alternatives or improvements
• Connect related issues or discussions

Best Practices:

• Read existing comments before posting
• Be respectful and constructive
• Stay on topic
• Use @mentions to involve specific people
• Format your comments clearly (use markdown)
• Follow up on your suggestions

Your perspective as a non-developer is valuable because:
• You represent end users
• You think about business and product implications
• You notice usability issues developers might miss
• You can help bridge technical and non-technical communities

sections.title: Common Workflows for Non-Developers
sections.body:
Here are step-by-step workflows for common tasks:

Workflow 1: Reporting a Documentation Error

1. Find the error in the documentation
2. Click "Edit" on the file
3. Make the correction
4. Propose the change with a clear message
5. Reference the issue if one exists

Workflow 2: Suggesting a New Feature

1. Search existing issues to avoid duplicates
2. Create a new issue with "Feature Request" label
3. Use the template: "As a [user], I want [feature] so that [benefit]"
4. Provide detailed context and use cases
5. Engage in discussion and refine the idea
6. Help prioritize if asked

Workflow 3: Improving Issue Organization

1. Identify organizational problems (missing labels, unclear templates)
2. Create an issue proposing improvements
3. Get community feedback
4. Create PRs to implement approved changes
5. Update documentation to reflect new processes

Workflow 4: Contributing User Stories

1. Identify a user need or pain point
2. Write user stories following the project's format
3. Create an issue or add to existing discussions
4. Help prioritize based on user value
5. Provide feedback as features are developed

Remember: Start small, learn the process, and gradually take on more complex contributions.

sections.title: Understanding Labels, Milestones, and Projects
sections.body:
GitHub provides organizational tools that help manage work. Understanding these helps you contribute more effectively.

Labels:

Labels categorize issues and PRs. Common labels include:
• bug, enhancement, documentation
• good first issue, help wanted
• priority: high/medium/low
• status: in-progress, blocked, needs-review

How to Use Labels:
• Filter issues by label to find work you can help with
• Suggest new labels if categories are missing
• Help maintainers organize by suggesting appropriate labels

Milestones:

Milestones group related issues toward a goal or release:
• Help identify what's planned for upcoming releases
• Show progress toward goals
• Help prioritize work

Projects:

Project boards visualize work using columns (e.g., To Do, In Progress, Done):
• See the big picture of project status
• Understand priorities and workflows
• Help organize and prioritize issues

As a non-developer, you can:
• Help organize issues into appropriate milestones
• Suggest labels for better categorization
• Contribute to project board organization
• Help prioritize based on user value

sections.title: Etiquette and Best Practices
sections.body:
Contributing to open source is about collaboration and respect. Here are guidelines for effective participation:

Communication:

• Be clear and concise
• Use proper grammar and formatting
• Be respectful and constructive
• Assume good intentions
• Thank maintainers for their work

Issue Management:

• Search before creating new issues
• One issue per problem or feature
• Keep issues focused and actionable
• Update issues with new information
• Close issues when resolved

Pull Requests:

• Make small, focused changes
• Write clear descriptions
• Reference related issues
• Respond to feedback promptly
• Be patient with reviews

Community:

• Help others when you can
• Share knowledge and experiences
• Recognize that maintainers are volunteers
• Be patient—open source moves at its own pace
• Celebrate wins and progress

Remember: You're joining a community. Building relationships and trust is just as important as the contributions you make.

sections.title: Real-World Examples
sections.body:
Here are examples of valuable non-developer contributions:

Example 1: Documentation Improvement

A product manager noticed that the onboarding guide was missing a crucial step. They:
• Created an issue describing the gap
• Proposed specific documentation changes
• Created a PR with the improvements
• Worked with maintainers to refine the wording
• Result: Better onboarding experience for all new users

Example 2: Feature Prioritization

A community member analyzed user feedback and:
• Compiled common feature requests
• Created a prioritized list with user value justification
• Facilitated discussion to reach consensus
• Result: Project roadmap aligned with user needs

Example 3: Process Improvement

A designer noticed that design proposals were getting lost. They:
• Proposed a new issue template for design proposals
• Created the template with appropriate fields
• Updated contribution guidelines
• Result: Better organization and visibility of design work

Example 4: User Research

A researcher conducted user interviews and:
• Documented findings in issues
• Created user personas
• Provided insights for feature development
• Result: More user-centered product decisions

These examples show that non-developer contributions are just as valuable as code contributions.

sections.title: Next Steps
sections.body:
Now that you understand the basics, here's how to get started:

1. Set up your GitHub account and complete your profile
2. Explore a project you're interested in
3. Read their contribution guidelines and code of conduct
4. Start small: fix a typo, report a bug, or ask a clarifying question
5. Gradually take on more complex contributions
6. Build relationships with the community
7. Share your experiences and help others get started

At Builder, we encourage everyone to contribute to open source projects. Whether you're writing code, improving documentation, or helping organize work, your contributions make a difference.

Remember: Every expert was once a beginner. The open source community values curiosity, helpfulness, and collaboration. Your unique perspective as a non-developer is an asset—use it to help build better products.

Ready to make your first contribution? Find a project you care about, start small, and don't be afraid to ask questions. The community is here to help.
